titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the George M.P. Baird Papers, ca. 1915-ca. 1960 CTC.1970.01
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Colleen Reilly.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2018-06-06T12:58-0400

did.abstract: This collection contains the papers, news clippings, and slides relating to lectures on the performing arts presented by George M. Baird. Baird was an English professor at the University of Pittsburgh from 1908-1961.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Baird, George M. P. (George Mahaffey Patterson)

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: George M.P. Baird, 1887-1970, B.A. University of Pittsburgh, 1909, made varied and lasting contributions to the University. He wrote the lyrics of the Alma Mater, suggested the Panthers as the name of the football team, and was actively associated with the Scottish Room Committee. He left his teaching position at Pitt for the Army in 1917. Upon his return, he began a new career in government service in the city of Pittsburgh and was senior research analyst for the Department of City Planning when he retired in 1961. Throughout his life he maintained a strong interest in the theatre. He wrote and produced several one-act plays, directed, served as a theatre consultant, and lectured on the theatre.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The clippings file is presently maintained largely as Mr. Baird had originally maintained it, although a new classification, "Names", has been added and some subject headings have been combined. Mr. Baird's headings and spelling have been retained on new folders, but in some cases revised in the inventory list following, for reasons of consistency, clarity and conformity. Included with the clippings are Mr. Baird's notes, papers and lectures.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of the Estate of George M. P. Baird in 1970.

odd.head: Previous Citation
odd.p: George M.P. Baird Papers, ca. 1915-1960, CTC.1970.01, Curtis Theatre Collection, Special Collections Department, University of Pittsburgh
Papers of George M. P. Baird, ca. 1915-1960, CTC.02, Curtis Theatre Collection, Special Collections Department, University of Pittsburgh

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: George M.P. Baird Papers, ca. 1915-1960, CTC.1970.01, Curtis Theatre Collection, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Curtis Theatre Collection Staff in 1970. Collection inventory re-engineered by Colleen Reilly in February 2007.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: Property rights reside with the University of Pittsburgh. For information about permission to reproduce or publish, please contact Special Collections.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The clippings file is presently maintained largely as Mr. Baird had it, although a new classification, Names, has been added and some subject headings have been combined. Mr. Baird's headings and spelling have been retained on new folders, but in some cases revised in the inventory list following, for reasons of consistency, clarity and conformity. Included with the clippings are Mr. Baird's notes, papers and lectures. There are nine subseries represented in their original order: Names, Shakespeare, Dance, Drama Topics, Drama Regions, Music, Stage, Theatre, and George M. Baird Productions and Publications.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The lecture materials in box 6 folder 18 correspond to the collection of slides that are in Series II.

scopecontent.p: One item from folder 13 titled Easter Miracle Drawing was oversized and moved to Curtis O/Miscellaneous 8.

did.unittitle: George M. Baird Productions and Publications

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains lantern slides utilized by George M. Baird in his lectures on theatre history and production. See Box 6, folder 18 for the lecture notes that correspond to these slides.
